items.label: Kinematics
Translational
v(avg) = s/t    average speed
v(avg)<sub>x</sub> = d<sub>x</sub>/t    average velocity
v(avg)<sub>y</sub> = d<sub>y</sub>/t    average velocity
a(avg)<sub>x</sub> = (vf<sub>x</sub> - vi<sub>x</sub>)/t
a(avg)<sub>y</sub> = (vf<sub>y</sub> - vi<sub>y</sub>)/t
d<sub>x</sub> = v0<sub>x</sub> t + 0.5 a<sub>x</sub> t<sup>2</sup>    [a<sub>x</sub> is constant]
d<sub>y</sub> = v0<sub>y</sub> t + 0.5 a<sub>y</sub> t<sup>2</sup>    [a<sub>y</sub> is constant]
vf<sub>x</sub> = vi<sub>x</sub> + a(avg)<sub>x</sub> t
vf<sub>y</sub> = vi<sub>y</sub> + a(avg)<sub>y</sub> t
v<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> = v0<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a<sub>x</sub> d<sub>x</sub>    [a<sub>x</sub> is constant]
v<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup> = v0<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a<sub>y</sub> d<sub>y</sub>    [a<sub>y</sub> is constant]
d<sub>x</sub> = v<sub>x</sub>   t    [a<sub>x</sub>=0; v<sub>x</sub> is constant]
d<sub>y</sub> = v<sub>y</sub>   t    [a<sub>y</sub>=0; v<sub>y</sub> is constant]
vf<sub>x</sub> = vi<sub>x</sub>
vf<sub>y</sub> = vi<sub>y</sub>
ac = v<sup>2</sup>/r    centripetal acceleration (instantaneous)
ac<sub>x</sub> = -v<sup>2</sup>/r r<sub>x</sub>/r    centripetal acceleration (x component)
ac<sub>y</sub> = -v<sup>2</sup>/r r<sub>y</sub>/r    centripetal acceleration (y component)
Vac<sub>x</sub> = Vab<sub>x</sub> + Vbc<sub>x</sub>    relative velocity
Vac<sub>y</sub> = Vab<sub>y</sub> + Vbc<sub>y</sub>    relative velocity
dnet<sub>x</sub> = d1<sub>x</sub> + d2<sub>x</sub> + ...    net displacement
dnet<sub>y</sub> = d1<sub>y</sub> + d2<sub>y</sub> + ...    net displacement
a = g    accel in free-fall
g = 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>    g near Earth
T = 2 π r/v    period of uniform circular motion
Rotational
ω<sub>z</sub> = θ<sub>z</sub>/t    average angular velocity
ωf<sub>z</sub> = ωi<sub>z</sub> + α(avg)<sub>z</sub> t    average anglular acceleration
α(avg)<sub>z</sub> = (ωf<sub>z</sub> - ωi<sub>z</sub>)/t    average anglular acceleration
θ<sub>z</sub> = ω0<sub>z</sub> t + 0.5 α<sub>z</sub> t<sup>2</sup>    [α<sub>z</sub> is constant]
ω<sub>z</sub><sup>2</sup> = ω0<sub>z</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 α<sub>z</sub> θ<sub>z</sub>    [α<sub>z</sub> is constant]
v = ω r    linear velocity at a certain radius
v = ω r    linear velocity of rolling object
Newton's Laws
Translational
F1<sub>x</sub> + F2<sub>x</sub> + ... = m a<sub>x</sub>    Newton's second law
F1<sub>y</sub> + F2<sub>y</sub> + ... = m a<sub>y</sub>    Newton's second law
Fnet<sub>x</sub> = F1<sub>x</sub> + F2<sub>x</sub> + ...    net force (x component)
Fnet<sub>y</sub> = F1<sub>y</sub> + F2<sub>y</sub> + ...    net force (y component)
Fof1on2 = Fof2on1    Newton's Third law (magnitudes)
F12<sub>x</sub> = - F21<sub>x</sub>    Newton's Third law (components)
F12<sub>y</sub> = - F21<sub>y</sub>    Newton's Third law (components)
Fg = G m1 m2/r<sup>2</sup>    universal gravitation
Force Laws
Fw = m g    weight law
Ff = μk Fn    kinetic friction
Ff = μs Fn    static friction (at max)
F = k d    Hooke's law
Ft1 = Ft2    equal tensions at both ends
F = v abs(dmdt)    thrust force (magnitudes)
F<sub>x</sub> = -v<sub>x</sub> dmdt    thrust force (x components)
F<sub>y</sub> = -v<sub>y</sub> dmdt    thrust force (y components)
F = K v<sup>2</sup>    drag force
Compound Bodies
M = m1 + m2 + ...    mass of compound
V = V1 + V2 + ...    volume of compound
v_compound = v_part    velocity of compound
v_compound = v_part    velocity of compound
F_on_part = F_on_compound    force on compound
Rotational
0 = τ1_z + τ2_z + ...    rotational form of Newton's 2nd law (α =0)
τnet<sub>z</sub> = I α<sub>z</sub>    rotational form of Newton's 2nd law
τ = r F sin(θ)    torque defined (magnitude)
τ<sub>x</sub> = r<sub>y</sub> F<sub>z</sub> - r<sub>z</sub> F<sub>y</sub>    torque defined (x component)
τ<sub>y</sub> = r<sub>z</sub> F<sub>x</sub> - r<sub>x</sub> F<sub>z</sub>    torque defined (y component)
τ<sub>z</sub> = r F sin(θF-θr)) or τ<sub>z</sub> = r<sub>x</sub> F<sub>y</sub> - r<sub>y</sub> F<sub>x</sub>    torque defined (z component)
τnet<sub>z</sub> = τ1<sub>z</sub> + τ2<sub>z</sub> + ...    net torque defined
Moment of Inertia
I = m R<sup>2</sup>    moment of point mass
I = M R<sup>2</sup> + Icm    parallel axis theorem
I = 0.5 m r<sup>2</sup>    disk about center
I = (1/12) m L<sup>2</sup>    rod about center
I = (1/3) m L<sup>2</sup>    rod about end
I = m r<sup>2</sup>    hoop
I = (1/12) m (L<sup>2</sup> + W<sup>2</sup>)    rectangular plate
I12 = I1 + I2    compound body
Work Energy and Power
W = F d cos(θ) or W = F<sub>x</sub> d<sub>x</sub> + F<sub>y</sub> d<sub>y</sub>    work defined
Wnet = WF1 + WF2 + ...    net work defined
Wnc = Wncf1 + Wncf2 + ...    work by non-conservative
Wnet = Kf - Ki    work-energy theorem
ME = KE + &Sigma Ui    mechanical energy defined
Wnc = ME2 - ME1    change in mechanical energy
ME1 = ME2    [Wnc=0] conservation of mechanical energy
U2 - U1 = -W12    definition of potential energy
KE = 0.5 m v<sup>2</sup>    kinetic energy defined
KE = 0.5 I ω<sup>2</sup>    rotational kinetic energy defined
Ug = m g h    gravitational potential energy
Ug = -G m1 m2/r    gravitational potential energy, spherical source
h2 - h1 = d12<sub>y</sub>    change in height
Us = 0.5 k d<sup>2</sup>    spring potential energy
U = q Vnet    electric potential energy
P(avg) = W/t    average power defined
Pnet = Wnet/t    average net power defined
P = F v cos(θ) or P = F<sub>x</sub> v<sub>x</sub> + F<sub>y</sub> v<sub>y</sub>    instantaneous power
P = 4 π r<sup>2</sup> I    relation of power and intensity (spherical emitter)
P = I A    relation of power and intensity (uniform over surface)
Inet = I1 + I2 + ...    net intensity defined
β = 10 log10(I/Iref)    intensity & decibels
I = Iref 10<sup>β/10</sup>    intensity & decibels
I = S    intensity & magnitude of the Poynting vector
Momentum and Impulse
Translational
p<sub>x</sub> = m v<sub>x</sub>    momentum defined (x component)
p<sub>y</sub> = m v<sub>y</sub>    momentum defined (y component)
p1i<sub>x</sub> + p2i<sub>x</sub> + ... = p1f<sub>x</sub> + p2f<sub>x</sub> + ...    conservation of momentum
p1i<sub>y</sub> + p2i<sub>y</sub> + ... = p1f<sub>y</sub> + p2f<sub>y</sub> + ...    conservation of momentum
KEf = KEi    elastic collision defined
J<sub>x</sub> = F(avg)<sub>x</sub> t    impulse and force
J<sub>y</sub> = F(avg)<sub>y</sub> t    impulse and force
J1<sub>x</sub> + J2<sub>x</sub> + ... = pf<sub>x</sub> - pi<sub>x</sub>    Newton's second law
J1<sub>y</sub> + J2<sub>y</sub> + ... = pf<sub>y</sub> - pi<sub>y</sub>    Newton's second law
J12 = J21    Newton's third law (magnitude)
J12<sub>x</sub> = -J21<sub>x</sub>    Newton's third law (x component)
J12<sub>y</sub> = -J21<sub>y</sub>    Newton's third law (y component)
Rcm<sub>x</sub> = (m1 r1<sub>x</sub> + m2 r2<sub>x</sub> + ...)/(m1 + m2 + ...)    center of mass
Rcm<sub>y</sub> = (m1 r1<sub>y</sub> + m2 r2<sub>y</sub> + ...)/(m1 + m2 + ...)    center of mass
Rotational
L<sub>z</sub> = I ω<sub>z</sub>    angular momentum defined
L1i<sub>z</sub> + L2i<sub>z</sub> + ... = L1f<sub>z</sub> + L2f<sub>z</sub> + ...    conservation of angular momentum
Fluids
P2 - P1 = ρ g (h1-h2)    pressure in fluid
0.5 ρ v1<sup>2</sup> + ρ g h1 + P1 = 0.5 ρ v2<sup>2</sup> + ρ g h2 + P2    Bernoulli equation
A1 v1 = A2 v2    equation of continuity
Fp = P A    pressure defined
ρ = m/V    mass density defined
Fb = ρf V g    Archimedes principle (buoyant force)
P = Pr0    point 1 open to atmosphere
Pr0 = 1.013E5 Pa    atmospheric pressure
Electricity and Magnetism
Q = N q    charged particles
F = kelec abs(q1 q2)/r<sup>2</sup>    Coulomb's law (magnitude)
F<sub>x</sub> = (kelec q1 q2/r<sup>2</sup>)   r<sub>x</sub>/r    Coulomb's law (x component)
F<sub>y</sub> = (kelec q1 q2/r<sup>2</sup>)   r<sub>y</sub>/r    Coulomb's law (y component)
F = abs(q) E    electric field (magnitude)
F<sub>x</sub> = q E<sub>x</sub>    electric field
F<sub>y</sub> = q E<sub>y</sub>    electric field
E = kelec abs(q)/r<sup>2</sup>    point charge field (magnitude)
E<sub>x</sub> = (kelec q/r<sup>2</sup>)   r<sub>x</sub>/r    point charge field (x component)
E<sub>y</sub> = (kelec q/r<sup>2</sup>)   r<sub>y</sub>/r    point charge field (y component)
Enet<sub>x</sub> = E1<sub>x</sub> + E2<sub>x</sub> + ...    net electric field (x component)
Enet<sub>y</sub> = E1<sub>y</sub> + E2<sub>y</sub> + ...    net electric field (y component)
Φe = A E cos(θE - θn) or Φe = A (E<sub>x</sub> n<sub>x</sub> + E<sub>y</sub> n<sub>y</sub>)    electric flux (uniform field)
dΦe/dt = E.n dA/dt    derivative of electric flux, uniform field
Φ = Φ1 + Φ2 + ...    adding fluxes
V = kelec q/r    point charge potential
Vnet = V1 + V2 + ...    net potential
U = q Vnet    electric potential energy
Φe = Q/ε0    Gauss' law
p = abs(q) r    electric dipole moment (magnitude)
p<sub>x</sub> = q r<sub>x</sub>    electric dipole moment (x component)
p<sub>y</sub> = q r<sub>y</sub>    electric dipole moment (y component)
τ = p E sin(θ)    torque for electric dipole (magnitude)
τ<sub>z</sub> = p E sin(θE-θp)) or τ<sub>z</sub> = p<sub>x</sub> E<sub>y</sub> - p<sub>y</sub> E<sub>x</sub>    torque for electric dipole (z component)
U = -p E cos(θp - θE) or U = -(p<sub>x</sub> E<sub>x</sub> + p<sub>y</sub> E<sub>y</sub>)    potential energy of electric dipole
F = abs(q) v B sin(θ)    magnetic force (magnitude)
F<sub>x</sub> = q (v<sub>y</sub> B<sub>z</sub> - v<sub>z</sub> B<sub>y</sub>)    magnetic force (x component)
F<sub>y</sub> = q (v<sub>z</sub> B<sub>x</sub> - v<sub>x</sub> B<sub>z</sub>)    magnetic force (y component)
F<sub>z</sub> = q v B sin(θB-θv) or F<sub>z</sub> = q (v<sub>x</sub> B<sub>y</sub> - v<sub>y</sub> B<sub>x</sub>)    magnetic force (z component)
F = I L B sin(θ)    magnetic force on a wire (magnitude)
B = μ0 abs(q) v sin(θ)/(4 π r<sup>2</sup>)    Biot-Savart law for a point charge (magnitude)
B<sub>x</sub> = μ0 q (v<sub>y</sub> n<sub>z</sub> - v<sub>z</sub> n<sub>y</sub>)/(4 π r<sup>2</sup>)    Biot-Savart law for a point charge (x component)
B<sub>y</sub> = μ0 q (v<sub>z</sub> n<sub>x</sub> - v<sub>x</sub> n<sub>z</sub>)/(4 π r<sup>2</sup>)    Biot-Savart law for a point charge (y component)

B<sub>z</sub> = μ0 q v sin(θn-θv)/(4 π r<sup>2</sup>) or B<sub>z</sub> = μ0 q (v<sub>x</sub> n<sub>y</sub> - v<sub>y</sub> n<sub>x</sub>)/(4 π r<sup>2</sup>)    Biot-Savart law for a point charge (z component)
B = μ0 I/(2 π r)    magnetic field of a straight wire
B = μ0 N I/(2 r)    magnetic field at center of a thin coil
B = μ0 n I    magnetic field inside a long solenoid
Bnet<sub>x</sub> = B1<sub>x</sub> + B2<sub>x</sub> + ...    net magnetic field (x component)
Bnet<sub>y</sub> = B1<sub>y</sub> + B2<sub>y</sub> + ...    net magnetic field (y component)
Bnet<sub>z</sub> = B1<sub>z</sub> + B2<sub>z</sub> + ...    net magnetic field (z component)
Φb = A B cos(θB - θn) or Φb = A (B<sub>x</sub> n<sub>x</sub> + B<sub>y</sub> n<sub>y</sub>)    magnetic flux (constant field)
dΦb/dt = B.n dA/dt    rate of change in magnetic flux (constant field)
V = -N dΦb/dt    Faraday's law
int B = μ0 (±I1 ± I2 ± ...)    Ampère's law
μ = N I A    magnetic dipole moment (magnitude)
μ<sub>x</sub> = N I A n<sub>x</sub>    magnetic dipole moment (x component)
μ<sub>y</sub> = N I A n<sub>y</sub>    magnetic dipole moment (y component)
μ<sub>z</sub> = N I A n<sub>z</sub>    magnetic dipole moment (z component)
τ = μ B sin(θ)    torque for magnetic dipole (magnitude)
τ<sub>x</sub> = μ<sub>y</sub> B<sub>z</sub> - μ<sub>z</sub> B<sub>y</sub>    torque for magnetic dipole (x component)
τ<sub>y</sub> = μ<sub>z</sub> B<sub>x</sub> - μ<sub>x</sub> B<sub>z</sub>    torque for magnetic dipole (y component)
τ<sub>z</sub> = μ B sin(θB-θμ)) or τ<sub>z</sub> = μ<sub>x</sub> B<sub>y</sub> - μ<sub>y</sub> B<sub>x</sub>    torque for magnetic dipole (z component)
U = -μ B cos(θμ - θB) or U = -(μ<sub>x</sub> B<sub>x</sub> + μ<sub>y</sub> B<sub>y</sub>)    potential energy of magnetic dipole
E = B c    ratio of fields in electromagnetic wave
Circuits
V1 + V2 + V3 ... = 0    Kirchoff's loop rule
Iin = Iout    Kirchoff's junction rule
P = V I    electric power
Resistance
Req = R1 + R2 + ...    equivalent resistance series
1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ...    equivalent resistance parallel
V = I R    Ohm's Law
Capacitance
C = q/V    capacitance defined
Ceq = C1 + C2 + ...    equivalent capacitance parallel
1/Ceq = 1/C1 + 1/C2 + ...    equivalent capacitance series
q1 = q2    charge on series capacitors
Qin = Qout    capacitor junction rule
U = 0.5 C V<sup>2</sup>    energy stored in a capacitor
τ = R C    RC time constant
q = C Vb (1 - exp(-t/τ))    charge on capacitor in RC circuit with battery
q = qi exp(-t/τ)    charge on capacitor in RC circuit
I = (Vb/R) exp(-t/τ)    current in RC circuit
q = fraction C Vb    RC charge as fraction of max
Inductance
V = -L dIdt    inductor EMF
V2 = -M12 dI1dt    mutual inductor EMF
U = 0.5 L I<sup>2</sup>    energy stored in inductor
L = μ0 N<sup>2</sup> A/l    self-inductance of long, uniform solenoid
τ = L/R    LR time constant
I = Imax (1 - exp(-t/τ))    LR current growth
Imax = Vb/R    LR growth final current
I = I0 exp(-t/τ)    LR current decay
I0 = Vb/R    LR circuit initial current
ω = 1/sqrt(L C)    LC angular frequency
τ = 2 L/R    RLC time constant
ω = sqrt(1/(L C)-R<sup>2</sup>/(2 L)<sup>2</sup>)    RLC angular frequency
V1/N1 = V2/N2    transformer voltage relation
P1 = P2    transformer power relation
Optics
1/do + 1/di = 1/f    thin lens/mirror equation
m = -di/do    (lateral) magnification
f = r/2    focal length of mirror
do2 = d12 - di1    combination of lenses
m12 = m1 m2    combined magnification
1/f12 = 1/f1 + 1/f2    compound lens (touching lenses)
n = c/v    index of refraction
n=1    index of refraction of vacuum
n1 sin(θ1) = n2 sin(θ2)    Snell's law
n1 sin(θ1) = n2    total internal reflection (minimum angle)
n1 tan(θ1) = n2    Brewster's law
If = Ii cos(θ)<sup>2</sup>    Malus' law
If = 0.5 Ii    polarizer and unpolarized light
d sin(θ) = n λ    interference for parallel slits
w sin(θ) = n λ    single slit diffraction (minima)
θ = 1.22 λ/d    resolution (circular)
Fp = 2 I/c    radiation pressure (reflector)
Waves and Oscillations
k = 2 π/λ    wavenumber
f = ω/(2 π)    frequency
T = 1/f    period of oscillation
vw = λ f or vw = ω/k    speed of a wave
vp = vw    speed of pulse is wave speed
vw = sqrt(Ft/μ)    speed of waves on a string
vmax = A ω    maximum speed of oscillation
amax = A ω<sup>2</sup>    maximum acceleration of oscillation
T = 2 π sqrt(m/k)    period of spring-mass system
T = 2 π sqrt(l/g)    period of simple pendulum
fo=fs (vw±vo)/(vw±vs)    frequency shift from doppler effect
fn = n f1 or λn = λ1/n    n-th harmonic
fbeat = abs(f1-f2)    beat frequency
E = Ei exp(-2 t/τ)    energy decay
vw = c    speed of light
Vectors and geometry
V<sub>x</sub> = V cos(θV - θx)    projecton on x-axis
V<sub>y</sub> = V sin(θV - θx)    projecton on y-axis
c<sup>2</sup> = a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>    Pythagorean Thm
A = sqrt(A<sub>x</sub><sup>2</sup> + A<sub>y</sub><sup>2</sup>)    vector magnitude
n = 1    length of unit vector
θ1 + θ2 = 90 deg    complimentary angles
θ1 + θ2 = 180 deg    supplementary angles
tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent    tangent for right triangle
A = w l    area of rectangle
dA/dt = w dl/dt    derivative of area of rectangle (constant width)
A = π r<sup>2</sup>    area of circle
c = 2 π r    circumference of circle
c = π d    circumference of circle
V = A l    volume of a cylinder
Connect Quantities
val1 = ±val2    equivalent quantities
θ12 = θ2 - θ1 or 180-(θ2-θ1)    angle between
|d| = s    distance & displacement
Icomp = Ibranch    current in branch
nf = (count forces)    number of forces
val1 = fraction val2    fraction of
R12 = R21    relative position equality
Rab2x = da12<sub>x</sub> - db12<sub>x</sub> Rab1<sub>x</sub>    relative position and displacement
Rab2y = da12<sub>y</sub> - db12<sub>y</sub> Rab1<sub>y</sub>    relative position and displacement
tac = tab + tbc    sum of times
sac = sab + sbc    sum distance traveled
rAC = rAB + rBC    sum collinear distances
a1 = a2    connected accelerations
v1 = v2    connected velocities
Ft1 = Ft2    equal tensions at both ends
r21<sub>x</sub> = x2 - x1    relative position from coordinates
r21<sub>y</sub> = y2 - y1    relative position from coordinates
λ = m/L    mass per unit length
n = N/l    turns per unit length
dy/dt<sub>a</sub>vg = (y2-y1)/(t2-t1)    average rate of change
